title: SUSY介绍(AQM作业)
content:
Homework of AQM，WI1

1. Explaination of SUSY QM method

SUSY QM stands for supersymmetric quantum mechanics, which has been applied widely in quantum mechanics. As we use dimensionless creation and annihilation operators to deal with harmonic oscillators, we can rewrite the operators in the following form:

A^†=12[W(x)−ddx];A^=12[W(x)+ddx]\hat{A}^\dagger = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left[W(x)-\frac{d}{dx}\right]; \hat{A}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left[W(x)+\frac{d}{dx}\right] ​A​^​​​†​​=​√​2​​​​​1​​[W(x)−​dx​​d​​];​A​^​​=​√​2​​​​​1​​[W(x)+​dx​​d​​]

where W(x)W(x)W(x) is an arbitrary function named as “superpotential”. This is our beginning point of SUSY method. As we have done with harmonic oscillator, we consider commutation relation between the two operators, for

A^†A^=12[W(x)2−∂2−W′(x)]\hat{A}^\dagger\hat{A} = \frac{1}{2}\left[W(x)^2-\partial^2-W'(x)\right] ​A​^​​​†​​​A​^​​=​2​​1​​[W(x)​2​​−∂​2​​−W​′​​(x)]

A^A^†=12[W(x)2−∂2+W′(x)]\hat{A}\hat{A}^\dagger = \frac{1}{2}\left[W(x)^2-\partial^2+W'(x)\right] ​A​^​​​A​^​​​†​​=​2​​1​​[W(x)​2​​−∂​2​​+W​′​​(x)]

the commutation relation reads

[A^,A^†]=W′(x)[\hat{A},\hat{A}^\dagger]=W'(x) [​A​^​​,​A​^​​​†​​]=W​′​​(x)

and the similar “number operator” reads

N^=A^†A^=H^−\hat{N} = \hat{A}^\dagger\hat{A} = \hat{H}_- ​N​^​​=​A​^​​​†​​​A​^​​=​H​^​​​−​​

the “number operator” we defined before is replaced by a Hamiltonian in SUSY method, and we can construct another Hamiltonian

H^+=A^A^†\hat{H}_+ = \hat{A}\hat{A}^\dagger ​H​^​​​+​​=​A​^​​​A​^​​​†​​

from the Hamiltonian we can get the pair of potentials

V−=W(x)2−W′(x)V_- = W(x)^2-W'(x) V​−​​=W(x)​2​​−W​′​​(x)

V+=W(x)2+W′(x)V_+ = W(x)^2+W'(x) V​+​​=W(x)​2​​+W​′​​(x)

the pair of Hamiltonians are positive definite. Now we check the relation between the two Hamiltonians and its eigen equations.

H^−∣n−⟩=En−∣n−⟩\hat{H}_- \vert n_-\rangle = E^-_n\vert n_- \rangle ​H​^​​​−​​∣n​−​​⟩=E​n​−​​∣n​−​​⟩

H^+∣n+⟩=En+∣n+⟩\hat{H}_+ \vert n_+ \rangle = E^+_n\vert n_+\rangle ​H​^​​​+​​∣n​+​​⟩=E​n​+​​∣n​+​​⟩

If H^−\hat{H}_-​H​^​​​−​​ does have a ground state ∣0−⟩\vert 0_- \rangle∣0​−​​⟩ with an energy 0
(when the supersymmetry is not broken), we can use SUSY QM method to solve our problem. The two Hamiltonians have almost the same energy spectrum expect ground state, and relation between them can be derived, which reads

En+=En+1−,E0−=0E_n^+ = E_{n+1}^-, E_0^- = 0 E​n​+​​=E​n+1​−​​,E​0​−​​=0

and the creation and annihilation operators must obey

A^∣n+1−⟩=En+1−∣n+⟩\hat{A}\vert n+1_-\rangle = \sqrt{E^-_{n+1}}\vert n_+\rangle ​A​^​​∣n+1​−​​⟩=√​E​n+1​−​​​​​∣n​+​​⟩

A^†∣n−⟩=En+∣n+1−⟩\hat{A}^\dagger \vert n_- \rangle = \sqrt{E^+_n}\vert n+1_-\rangle ​A​^​​​†​​∣n​−​​⟩=√​E​n​+​​​​​∣n+1​−​​⟩

The following relation is similar to the harmonic oscillator case, making the SUSY QM method possible. The pair Hamiltonian is closely related, and we can construct the series of pair Hamiltonian to get the energie levels and eigenstates of the system. But first, we must get the information about the ground state. Under the italic condition we can have

A^∣0−⟩=0\hat{A}\vert 0_- \rangle = 0 ​A​^​​∣0​−​​⟩=0

from which we can easily solve the eigen function of the ground state by

W(x)dx=−dlnψ0−(x)W(x)dx = -d\ln \psi^-_0(x) W(x)dx=−dlnψ​0​−​​(x)

which can be simplified as

ψ0−(x)=Cexp(−∫x0xW(x)dx)\psi_0^-(x)=C\exp (-\int^x_{x_0} W(x)dx ) ψ​0​−​​(x)=Cexp(−∫​x​0​​​x​​W(x)dx)

From the following procedure we can fully solve the system. However, there are two keypoints in the following SUSY method. The first point is to construct a proper superpotential W(x)W(x)W(x). And the second one is the system must obey the italic condition. In other words, the symmetry of the system must remain unbroken. If the pair of potentials are shape invarient, the symmetry is not broken.
So what is shape invarience? If a pair of potentials are similar, which in mathematic words reads

V+(x,a0)=V−(x,a1)+2C(a1)V_+(x,a_0)=V_-(x,a_1)+2C(a_1) V​+​​(x,a​0​​)=V​−​​(x,a​1​​)+2C(a​1​​)

where a stands for parameters and a1=f(a0)a_1 = f(a_0)a​1​​=f(a​0​​), then the potential is shape invarient. Shape invarience is related to the range of SUSY QM method. If a system has shape invarience, we can use SUSY QM method to get simple algebra relation. Otherwise SUSY QM method may not be proper to handle the system.

The energy spectrum of a shape invarient system reads

En0=E00+∑i=1nC(ai)E_n^0 = E^0_0 + \sum_{i=1}^n C(a_i) E​n​0​​=E​0​0​​+​i=1​∑​n​​C(a​i​​)

without solving any differential equation.

So let’s turn to the construction of the Hamilton series. If we have a pair of Hamiltonian describing ground state, noted as H^0−=H^0\hat{H}^-_0 = \hat{H}_0​H​^​​​0​−​​=​H​^​​​0​​ and H^0+=H^1\hat{H}^+_0=\hat{H}_1​H​^​​​0​+​​=​H​^​​​1​​, we can construct a Hamiltonian pair corresponding to H^1−=H^1\hat{H}^-_1 = \hat{H}_1​H​^​​​1​−​​=​H​^​​​1​​ and H^1+=H^2\hat{H}^+_1=\hat{H}_2​H​^​​​1​+​​=​H​^​​​2​​ …

If the energy of the ground state is not zero,

H^0=A^0†A^0+E0=−∂2+V0(x)\hat{H}_0 = \hat{A}^\dagger_0\hat{A}_0+E_0=-\partial^2+V_0(x) ​H​^​​​0​​=​A​^​​​0​†​​​A​^​​​0​​+E​0​​=−∂​2​​+V​0​​(x)

where these operators correspond to the minus case. The first Hamiltonian is

H^1=A^0A^0†+E0=−∂2+V1(x)\hat{H}_1 = \hat{A}_0\hat{A}^\dagger_0+E_0=-\partial^2+V_1(x) ​H​^​​​1​​=​A​^​​​0​​​A​^​​​0​†​​+E​0​​=−∂​2​​+V​1​​(x)

with

V1(x)=V+0(x)V_1(x) = V^0_+(x) V​1​​(x)=V​+​0​​(x)

and the information about the energy eigen states

En+10=En1E^0_{n+1} = E^1_n E​n+1​0​​=E​n​1​​

A^0ψn+10=En+10−E00ψn1\hat{A}_0\psi_{n+1}^0 = \sqrt{E_{n+1}^0-E_0^0} \psi^1_n ​A​^​​​0​​ψ​n+1​0​​=√​E​n+1​0​​−E​0​0​​​​​ψ​n​1​​

Now construct the first operator pair, with

H^1=A^1A^1†+E01\hat{H}_1 = \hat{A}_1\hat{A}_1^\dagger + E^1_0 ​H​^​​​1​​=​A​^​​​1​​​A​^​​​1​†​​+E​0​1​​

with a new superpotential

W1(x)=ψ01 ′(x)/ψ01(x)W_1 (x) = \psi _0 ^1 \ ' (x) / \psi _0 ^1 (x) W​1​​(x)=ψ​0​1​​ ​′​​(x)/ψ​0​1​​(x)

thus we can give out the operators

A^1=∂+W1(x)\hat{A}_1 = \partial + W_1(x) ​A​^​​​1​​=∂+W​1​​(x)

and

A^1†=−∂+W1(x)\hat{A}_1^\dagger = -\partial + W_1(x) ​A​^​​​1​†​​=−∂+W​1​​(x)

from the previous procedure we can have information about the eigen state of the second Hamiltonian and a infinit series of Hamiltonian

H^k=A^kA^k†+E0k=−∂2+Vk(x)\hat{H}_k = \hat{A}_k\hat{A}_k^\dagger + E_0^k = -\partial^2 + V_k(x) ​H​^​​​k​​=​A​^​​​k​​​A​^​​​k​†​​+E​0​k​​=−∂​2​​+V​k​​(x)

where

Wk(x)=ψ0k ′(x)/ψ0k(x)W_k(x) = \psi_0^k\ '(x)/\psi_0^k(x) W​k​​(x)=ψ​0​k​​ ​′​​(x)/ψ​0​k​​(x)

and

A^k=∂+Wk(x)\hat{A}_k = \partial + W_k(x) ​A​^​​​k​​=∂+W​k​​(x)

and

A^k†=−∂+Wk(x)\hat{A}_k^\dagger = -\partial + W_k(x) ​A​^​​​k​†​​=−∂+W​k​​(x)

the state is given by

Enk=Ek+n0E_n^k = E^0_{k+n} E​n​k​​=E​k+n​0​​

and

ψnk=A^k−1⋯A^0ψn+k0(En+k0−Ek−10)⋯(En+k0−E00)\psi_n^k = \frac{\hat{A}_{k-1}\cdots\hat{A}_0 \psi^0_{n+k}}{\sqrt{(E_{n+k}^0-E_{k-1}^0)\cdots (E_{n+k}^0-E_0^0)}} ψ​n​k​​=​√​(E​n+k​0​​−E​k−1​0​​)⋯(E​n+k​0​​−E​0​0​​)​​​​​​A​^​​​k−1​​⋯​A​^​​​0​​ψ​n+k​0​​​​

thus we can restore the information about the zero-th Hamiltonian H^0\hat{H}_0​H​^​​​0​​

ψk0=A^0†⋯A^k−1†ψ0k(E10−E00)⋯(Ek0−E00)\psi^0_k = \frac{\hat{A}^\dagger_0\cdots\hat{A}^\dagger_{k-1}\psi_0^k}{\sqrt{(E_1^0-E_0^0)\cdots (E_k^0-E_0^0)}} ψ​k​0​​=​√​(E​1​0​​−E​0​0​​)⋯(E​k​0​​−E​0​0​​)​​​​​​A​^​​​0​†​​⋯​A​^​​​k−1​†​​ψ​0​k​​​​

2. Solution

name of potential W(x)W(x)W(x) potential V−(x)V_-(x)V​−​​(x)
shifted oscillator 12ωx−b\frac{1}{2}\omega x-b​2​​1​​ωx−b 14ω2(x−2bω)2−ω2\frac{1}{4}\omega^2(x-\frac{2b}{\omega})^2-\frac{\omega}{2}​4​​1​​ω​2​​(x−​ω​​2b​​)​2​​−​2​​ω​​
three-dimensional oscillator 12ωr−l+1r\frac{1}{2}\omega r - \frac{l+1}{r}​2​​1​​ωr−​r​​l+1​​ 14ω2r2+l(l+1)r2−(l+32)ω\frac{1}{4}\omega^2r^2+\frac{l(l+1)}{r^2}-(l+\frac{3}{2})\omega​4​​1​​ω​2​​r​2​​+​r​2​​​​l(l+1)​​−(l+​2​​3​​)ω
Morse A−Bexp(−αx)A-B\exp (-\alpha x)A−Bexp(−αx) A2+B2exp(−2αx)−2B(A+α/2)exp(−αx)A^2+B^2\exp (-2\alpha x)-2B(A+\alpha /2)\exp (-\alpha x)A​2​​+B​2​​exp(−2αx)−2B(A+α/2)exp(−αx)

2.1 Shifted oscillator

Let’s take shifted oscillator as an example. The zeroth creation and annihilation operators are

A^†=12[12ωx−b−∂];A^=12[12ωx−b+∂]\hat{A}^\dagger = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left[\frac{1}{2}\omega x-b-\partial\right];\hat{A} = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left[\frac{1}{2}\omega x-b+\partial\right] ​A​^​​​†​​=​√​2​​​​​1​​[​2​​1​​ωx−b−∂];​A​^​​=​√​2​​​​​1​​[​2​​1​​ωx−b+∂]

thus the first two Hamiltonians are

H^0=A^†A^=12[(12ωx−b)2−∂2−12ω]\hat{H}_0=\hat{A}^\dagger\hat{A}=\frac{1}{2}\left[(\frac{1}{2}\omega x-b)^2-\partial^2-\frac{1}{2}\omega\right] ​H​^​​​0​​=​A​^​​​†​​​A​^​​=​2​​1​​[(​2​​1​​ωx−b)​2​​−∂​2​​−​2​​1​​ω]

H^1=A^A^†=12[(12ωx−b)2−∂2+12ω]\hat{H}_1=\hat{A}\hat{A}^\dagger=\frac{1}{2}\left[(\frac{1}{2}\omega x-b)^2-\partial^2+\frac{1}{2}\omega\right] ​H​^​​​1​​=​A​^​​​A​^​​​†​​=​2​​1​​[(​2​​1​​ωx−b)​2​​−∂​2​​+​2​​1​​ω]

with the pair of potentials:

V−=(12ωx−b)2−12ωV_- = (\frac{1}{2}\omega x-b)^2-\frac{1}{2}\omega V​−​​=(​2​​1​​ωx−b)​2​​−​2​​1​​ω

V+=(12ωx−b)2+12ωV_+ = (\frac{1}{2}\omega x-b)^2+\frac{1}{2}\omega V​+​​=(​2​​1​​ωx−b)​2​​+​2​​1​​ω

The energy spectrum can be derived without solving differential equation using the shape invarience

V+−V−=ωV_+ - V_- = \omega V​+​​−V​−​​=ω

thus the potential is shape invarient. The energy spectrum reads

En0=∑i=1nC(ai)=nω/2, where ai stands for parametersE_n^0 = \sum_{i=1}^n C(a_i) = n\omega/2,\ where\ a_i\ stands\ for\ parameters E​n​0​​=​i=1​∑​n​​C(a​i​​)=nω/2, where a​i​​ stands for parameters

We can solve the ground state of H^0\hat{H}_0​H​^​​​0​​ using the equation

A^0∣0⟩=0\hat{A}_0\vert 0 \rangle = 0 ​A​^​​​0​​∣0⟩=0

or in other form

12[12ωx−b+∂]ψ00(x)=0\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left[\frac{1}{2}\omega x-b+\partial\right]\psi_0^0(x)=0 ​√​2​​​​​1​​[​2​​1​​ωx−b+∂]ψ​0​0​​(x)=0

one gets

ψ00(x)=N0exp(−14ωx2+bx)\psi_0^0(x)=N_0\exp(-\frac{1}{4}\omega x^2+bx) ψ​0​0​​(x)=N​0​​exp(−​4​​1​​ωx​2​​+bx)

with E00=0E_0^0 = 0E​0​0​​=0 and N0=(ω/2π)1/4N_0 = (\omega / 2\pi)^{1/4}N​0​​=(ω/2π)​1/4​​. Assume the first pair of operators has the form

A^1=12[∂+W1(x)],A^1†=12[−∂+W1(x)]\hat{A}_1 = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}[\partial + W_1(x)],\hat{A}_1^\dagger = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}[-\partial + W_1(x)] ​A​^​​​1​​=​√​2​​​​​1​​[∂+W​1​​(x)],​A​^​​​1​†​​=​√​2​​​​​1​​[−∂+W​1​​(x)]

then

W12(x)−W1′(x)−∂2=2H^1W_1^2(x) - W_1'(x) - \partial^2 = 2 \hat{H}_1 W​1​2​​(x)−W​1​′​​(x)−∂​2​​=2​H​^​​​1​​

W12(x)−W1′(x)=(12ωx−b)2+ω2−E01W_1^2(x)-W_1'(x) = (\frac{1}{2}\omega x-b)^2+\frac{\omega}{2} - E_0^1 W​1​2​​(x)−W​1​′​​(x)=(​2​​1​​ωx−b)​2​​+​2​​ω​​−E​0​1​​

assume the solution W1(x)=a1x−b1W_1(x) = a_1x-b_1W​1​​(x)=a​1​​x−b​1​​ and solve the equation, one can get

W1(x)=12ωx−bW_1(x) = \frac{1}{2}\omega x - b W​1​​(x)=​2​​1​​ωx−b

that’s exactly the same as the zeroth superpotential W0(x)W_0(x)W​0​​(x), so the first pair of operators is the same as the zeroth pair. Considering the commutation relation

[A^,A^†]=ω[\hat{A},\hat{A}^\dagger] = \omega [​A​^​​,​A​^​​​†​​]=ω

the n-th Hamiltonian reads

H^n=12[(12ωx−b)2−∂2+2n−12ω]\hat{H}_n = \frac{1}{2}\left[(\frac{1}{2}\omega x-b)^2-\partial^2+\frac{2n-1}{2}\omega\right] ​H​^​​​n​​=​2​​1​​[(​2​​1​​ωx−b)​2​​−∂​2​​+​2​​2n−1​​ω]

with the previous procedure, every superpotential, along with pair of creation and annilihation operators have exactly the same form as in the zeroth Hamiltonian. Moreover the ground state of the n-th Hamiltonian has the same wavefunction as ψ00(x)\psi_0^0(x)ψ​0​0​​(x). So we have:

ψn0(x)=A^0†A^1†⋯A^n−1†ψ00(x)n!ωn=(A^†)nn!ωnψ00(x)\psi_n^0(x) = \frac{\hat{A}_0^\dagger\hat{A}_1^\dagger\cdots\hat{A}^\dagger_{n-1}\psi^0_0(x)}{\sqrt{n!\omega^n}}=\frac{(\hat{A}^\dagger)^n}{\sqrt{n!\omega^n}}\psi^0_0(x) ψ​n​0​​(x)=​√​n!ω​n​​​​​​​​A​^​​​0​†​​​A​^​​​1​†​​⋯​A​^​​​n−1​†​​ψ​0​0​​(x)​​=​√​n!ω​n​​​​​​​(​A​^​​​†​​)​n​​​​ψ​0​0​​(x)

or

ψn0(x)=1n!(2ω)n(12ωx−b−∂)nψ00(x)\psi_n^0(x) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{n!(2\omega)^n}}(\frac{1}{2}\omega x-b-\partial)^n\psi_0^0(x) ψ​n​0​​(x)=​√​n!(2ω)​n​​​​​​​1​​(​2​​1​​ωx−b−∂)​n​​ψ​0​0​​(x)

which is just the same as a harmonic oscillator with a shift in position.

2.2 Three dimensional harmonic oscillator

In this case we only solve the energy spectum, for the presentation may not last a long time. The zeroth creation and annihilation operators are

A^†=12[12ωr−l+1r−∂];A^=12[12ωr−l+1r+∂]\hat{A}^\dagger = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left[\frac{1}{2}\omega r - \frac{l+1}{r}-\partial\right];\hat{A} = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left[\frac{1}{2}\omega r - \frac{l+1}{r}+\partial\right] ​A​^​​​†​​=​√​2​​​​​1​​[​2​​1​​ωr−​r​​l+1​​−∂];​A​^​​=​√​2​​​​​1​​[​2​​1​​ωr−​r​​l+1​​+∂]

thus the first two Hamiltonians are

H^0=A^†A^=12[(12ωr−l+1r)2−∂2−(12ω+l+1r2)]\hat{H}_0=\hat{A}^\dagger\hat{A}=\frac{1}{2}\left[(\frac{1}{2}\omega r - \frac{l+1}{r})^2-\partial^2-(\frac{1}{2}\omega + \frac{l+1}{r^2})\right] ​H​^​​​0​​=​A​^​​​†​​​A​^​​=​2​​1​​[(​2​​1​​ωr−​r​​l+1​​)​2​​−∂​2​​−(​2​​1​​ω+​r​2​​​​l+1​​)]

H^1=A^A^†=12[(12ωr−l+1r)2−∂2+(12ω+l+1r2)]\hat{H}_1=\hat{A}\hat{A}^\dagger=\frac{1}{2}\left[(\frac{1}{2}\omega r - \frac{l+1}{r})^2-\partial^2+(\frac{1}{2}\omega + \frac{l+1}{r^2})\right] ​H​^​​​1​​=​A​^​​​A​^​​​†​​=​2​​1​​[(​2​​1​​ωr−​r​​l+1​​)​2​​−∂​2​​+(​2​​1​​ω+​r​2​​​​l+1​​)]

with the pair of potentials:

V−=(12ωr−l+1r)2−(12ω+l+1r2)V_- = (\frac{1}{2}\omega r - \frac{l+1}{r})^2-(\frac{1}{2}\omega + \frac{l+1}{r^2}) V​−​​=(​2​​1​​ωr−​r​​l+1​​)​2​​−(​2​​1​​ω+​r​2​​​​l+1​​)

V+=(12ωr−l+1r)2+(12ω+l+1r2)V_+ = (\frac{1}{2}\omega r - \frac{l+1}{r})^2+(\frac{1}{2}\omega + \frac{l+1}{r^2}) V​+​​=(​2​​1​​ωr−​r​​l+1​​)​2​​+(​2​​1​​ω+​r​2​​​​l+1​​)

rewrite the two potentials, assuming l′=l+1l' = l+1l​′​​=l+1

V−(r;l)=14ω2r2+l(l+1)r2−(l+32)ωV_-(r;l) = \frac{1}{4}\omega^2r^2+\frac{l(l+1)}{r^2}-(l+\frac{3}{2})\omega V​−​​(r;l)=​4​​1​​ω​2​​r​2​​+​r​2​​​​l(l+1)​​−(l+​2​​3​​)ω

V+(r;l)=14ω2r2+l′(l′+1)r2−(l+12)ωV_+(r;l) = \frac{1}{4}\omega^2r^2+\frac{l'(l'+1)}{r^2}-(l+\frac{1}{2})\omega V​+​​(r;l)=​4​​1​​ω​2​​r​2​​+​r​2​​​​l​′​​(l​′​​+1)​​−(l+​2​​1​​)ω

for

V+(r;l)−V−(r;l′)=ω×(l′−l+1)V_+(r;l) - V_-(r;l') = \omega \times (l'-l+1) V​+​​(r;l)−V​−​​(r;l​′​​)=ω×(l​′​​−l+1)

we have

a1=a0+1=l+1a_1 = a_0 + 1 = l + 1 a​1​​=a​0​​+1=l+1

and the potential is shape invarient, which means

Appendix B: SUSY in a nutshell 用人话讲SUSY

咳咳，好的，上面给出了SUSY的公式框架还有作业pre的内容。接下来我会尝试用简单而不那么严肃的语言叙述SUSY方法。
“超对称量子力学”太高大上了，我们换个说法——“二次量子化表象”或者是“占有数表象”，没错，就是你们在量子力学或者甚至化院的课上见到的那套产生-湮灭算符的方法。如果我们能够像谐振子势一样把势能拆了，那么是不是就能像谐振子势一样用升降算符解这个体系了呢？会有一些差别，但是基本思想是不变的。
那么我们先构造一对产生-湮灭算符，构造的方法是用合适的含有坐标的函数W(x)W(x)W(x)替换掉升降算符中的xxx——这个函数被我们称为“超对称势”，在讨论方法的适用性之前我们不妨假定我们可以任意取这个函数——看起来似乎很美好。由此，按照上面的路子，我们像是谐振子一样研究算符之间的对易关系，和相应的“粒子数算符”（其实这里并不能称为粒子数算符了，而是超对称哈密顿对中的一个哈密顿量）。有了这两个关系，我们就可以看看产生湮灭算符作用在“粒子数算符”的本征态上的作用结果——
且慢！我们看一眼上面的过程，再瞅一眼Appendix A里面的推导过程——当我们换成W(x)W(x)W(x)的时候，有些不妙的事情发生了：产生-湮灭算符作用到粒子数算符的本征态上，通常得到的态不再是粒子数算符的本征态。
喝口水，消消气：谐振子毕竟是特殊的情况，一般化推广的时候难免会有一些问题。冷静一下，好好看看，产生-湮灭算符连接的本征态不再是单一算符的本征态，而是A^A^†\hat{A}\hat{A}^\dagger​A​^​​​A​^​​​†​​和A^†A^\hat{A}^\dagger\hat{A}​A​^​​​†​​​A​^​​之间。在谐振子之间，这两个算符仅相差一个常数，而且本征态的能级正好可以“平移重合”的——所以在谐振子情况下连接同一个算符的不同态可以看成这种情况的特殊情况。谐振子毕竟是特殊情况，我们终于可以安慰自己至少和谐振子还是相容的。由于这两个算符都有哈密顿量的性质，我们不妨把它们记作一对哈密顿量，这就是一对超对称的哈密顿量。在SUSY的一般做法中，事情不像是谐振子那么简单——负的哈密顿量的第一激发态需要由正的哈密顿量的基态以产生算符作用得到。
如果我们需要知道更高的态呢？来！我们把正的哈密顿量作为一对新对的负的哈密顿量，然后构造出与之对应的正哈密顿量——很拗口，所以我们不妨把这些哈密顿量以0,1,2…标记，得到无穷的哈密顿量序列。哈密顿量0的第n个能量本征态需要从哈密顿量n的基态连续作用n次不同的产生算符得到——没错，每一对哈密顿量都要重新定义超对称势、产生湮灭算符和哈密顿量对！这就是“超对称量子力学”的做法，精神上和谐振子的二次量子化是相同的，只不过“略微”复杂了些。
那这堆操作数学上行不行呢？这是由所谓的“形状不变性”(shape invariance)决定的。简而言之，其数学表述是第一个哈密顿量对的势能之间相差一个参数——不含坐标的参数，而这一条件若成立，那么SUSY的上述哈密顿量构造后都是相类似的——有着良好的递推性质。关于这一性质的证明我没有做，但是可以看一下相关的文章。另外，这样有一个更显而易见的好处——我们可以不经过求解微分方程就能得到系统的能级！
